item.title: The Negative Confessions
item.description: From the Book of the Dead, the Ancient Egyptian funerary text. I harmed no one. I made neither my relatives nor my companions unhappy. I did no vile act on the Abode of Truth. I had no acquaintance with evil. I did no evil. I made no one work beyond their capabilities. I caused no one to suffer, nor to be fearful, poor or wretched. I did not do what the gods hate.

item.title: A question for literature nerds...
item.description: One of my favorite passages in Cormac McCarthy's All The Pretty Horses comes about three quarters of the way through... The hero has been through hell and he's about to find out if it was all worth it. In some sense everything in the book has been pointing to what is about to happen. All this intensity has built up‚Ä¶ ...and then he's forced to wait. If I remember right, he's literally waiting for a train.

item.title: The Five Senses
item.description: The one where you know someone is behind you. The one where you know a friend has had a bad day. The one where you're forgetting something and you know it but you have no idea what it is. The one where you know you're getting sick even though you have no symptoms. The one where you're holding a flimsy full plastic drink cup and you know it's on the verge of slipping even though it hasn't slipped yet.

item.title: Dehumanizing Etymology
item.description: Source for all: etymonline.com Assassin A fanatical Ismaili Muslim sect of the mountains of Lebanon in the time of the Crusades, under leadership of the "Old Man of the Mountains" Coward mid-13c., from Old French coart "coward" from coe "tail," from Latin coda, popular dialect variant of cauda "tail,"; The word probably reflects an animal metaphoric sense still found in expressions like turning tail and tail between legs. Fanatic 1520s, "insane person," from Latin fanaticus "mad, enthusiastic, inspired by a god," also "furious, mad," originally, "pertaining to a temple,"

item.title: Everything You Ever Wanted to Know about the Filibuster
item.description: You will read a lot over the next few weeks about how the filibuster is an essential part of our checks and balances installed by the founders to protect us from the mob. That Republicans have unilaterally undermined that protection. This is baloney. (My primary source is: http://www.law.harvard.edu/students/orgs/jlpp/Gold_Gupta_JLPP_article.pdf ) The filibuster allows a minority party in the senate to undermine progress through ‚Äúdilatory‚Äù debate: debate only for the purpose of delay, rather than persuasion.

item.title: Trepidatious is apparently not a word*
item.description: I love language. Learned this the other day. Follow the steps… (* in the prescriptivist sense. It is obviously a word by usage.) There's an old word "Trepid". OED calls it "rare" meaning nobody really uses it anymore. It is an adjective. Fun fact: from Latin, related to "trep-" "to tremble". Aside: From trepid we get the much more common word "Intrepid." Not "rare" at all. Trepid has a noun form "Trepidation" from the Latin Trepidare ‚Üí Trepidationem.

item.title: What to do when someone includes you on an email that obviously has too many people on the CC list
item.description: Professional advice from a computer professional. Check to see if anybody has already responded informing the sender of the mistake. If so DO NOTHING. It will end eventually. If not, reply ONLY to the sender informing them of the error. Ask them to reply to the original email, explain the mistake, and move everyone to the BCC list on the reply. This way hopefully the impending flood of future replies will only go to the original sender.

item.title: I don't know. I just don't know.
item.description: I've always had the sense that maybe my perception is broken. Like sometimes people talk about how beautiful some instrumental music is... And I kind of think asking which of two noises is prettier... Is like asking which of two colors tastes better. It's sound right? I mean I can tell when something is grating and awful but above that threshold it's all kind of an ambiguous mash of "sure sounds fine I guess.

item.title: Recurring Dreams
item.description: Brakes don't work. Usually when backing up. Driving across an irrationally rickety bridge. Like two 2x4s stretched across an enormous chasm. Fall in the water. Have to cross the water carefully without falling in. Have to get in the water but it is gross and dirty. Apparently I have a thing with water. Alligators. In many precarious situations. I really really really really hate alligators when I'm asleep. One of my daughters gets eaten by a fish and I have to cut her out.

item.title: A Message to Privileged Progressives
item.description: I wrote this last night on Facebook (where I go to be close to the people I know personally). I’m still processing but I thought it probably had a place here too. America learned a lesson tonight. I think it is fair to say that Trump found a market for his populist appeal despite his hatefulness, and we who were so deeply opposed to his presidency should not ignore that. Many Trump supporters don‚Äôt trust their leaders to attend to their needs.

item.title: My Fold
item.description: I don't have a fold. Or perhaps I am my fold. And you are your fold. Always apart. And for that reason we are the same. And so the whole universe is my fold. And I welcome you to it. As you welcome me.

item.title: Muse
item.description: From Rabindranath Tagore’s immeasurably beautiful Gitanjali. " On the day when the lotus bloomed, alas, my mind was straying, and I knew it not. My basket was empty and the flower remained unheeded. Only now and again a sadness fell upon me, and I started up from my dream and felt a sweet trace of a strange fragrance in the south wind. That vague sweetness made my heart ache with longing and it seemed to me that it was the eager breath of the summer seeking for its completion.

item.title: Seven Sins of Writing
item.description: Sentimental ~ This is unearned emotion. If you tell me she's devastated, if you tell me her voice cracks, if you show me her tears, none of that matters if any of it had to be said. "Like great works, deep feelings always mean more than they are conscious of saying." ‚Äî Albert Camus Contrived ~ This is unearned circumstance. He can't just think very hard or be especially earnest to make his weakness disappear.

item.title: My Cat Waits for Me to Pee
item.description: My cat waits for me to pee. He waits very patiently. At my feet. And when I stand he stands. And looks up excitedly. I flush. And he jumps up on the toilet seat. He watches the water swirl. With obvious feline anticipation. And then he drinks. A long careful deliberate drink. Every time. But only when I use the guest bathroom. He has a water bowl. This is weird right?

item.title: The Moon Illusion
item.description: This finally makes sense to me. You know how the moon often looks bigger on the horizon than when it is high in the sky? Of course the moon hasn't actually changed size. This is the "Moon Illusion". But perhaps you will be surprised to learn that it's "apparent size" (which is to say it's measurable angular size ‚Äî how big it actually looks to your physical eyes) is also unchanged.

item.title: Things I Love That Most People Don't Seem to Love

History. Never not interesting.

item.title: The Problem with Television
item.description: The problem with television is it all happens so fast. Like I'm about to finally get around to watching West Wing. Because everyone said it was really really good. But we're past that now right? Should I just skip right past Sopranos, Downton Abbey, and Game of Thrones... ...And dive right in to Stranger Things or whatever it is called? I guess what I mean is how do you get on this moving train without losing your legs?

item.title: On Primaries

Anybody can run for president if they meet the constitutional requirements.

item.description: I don’t mean to be bossy but @Lindi is right and this is another smart take. https://storify.com/davechensky/clay-shirky-on-not-getting-complacent

item.title: Reason We Were Late
item.description: My kids’ elementary school had a form you had to sign when you were late. It asked why you were late. This is none of their business of course (not that I fault them for asking). These are the reasons I gave over the years. I hope they’re in a database somewhere. Misplaced glass eye. Tragic boating accident. Incident with dental floss and goldfish. Turns out the school is EAST.

item.title: THINGS THAT HAPPENED ON MY BIRTHDAY
item.description: 1649: Elie Wiesel's fictional trial of God takes place. 1713: Frederick the First of Prussia, grandfather of Frederick the Great, dies. 1759: Authorities attempt to seize all printed copies of Voltaire's Candide in Paris on the grounds that it is seditious. 1836: The patent for the Colt revolver pistol is granted. 1870: The first African American senator is sworn in. 1932: Adolf Hitler becomes a German citizen. 1952: A solar eclipse is visible in Europe.

item.title: I saw Ghost Busters
item.description: Fair disclosure: I'm not really a fan of the original. I genuinely don't get why it is so popular. I was really young when I first saw it though so maybe that tainted me. I have tried twice to re-watch it as an adult but got bored and turned it off both times. None of this is a dig at the movie itself. Lots of people I admire love this movie like a child.

item.title: YOU HAVE A DOZEN DONUTS TO BUY, WHAT IS THE PREFECT COMBINATION?
item.description: Inspired by @wallflower, who I respect immensely but she is misguided. From Rainbow Doughnuts in north phoenix (not the same as rainbow doughnuts in east phoenix). 5 glazed raised. The best overall doughnut. 2 apple fritters. The best imposter doughnut. 2 glazed buttermilk. So good. 2 chocolate buttermilk. Ditto. 2 Boston cream. But only if it's pastry cream inside. If it's frosting-filled, cancel your order and burn the place down.

item.title: Kinds of French Toast
item.description: I’m an expert French Toast maker here to tell you what you’re doing wrong. With apologies to @Lisa_Fav and @MaiaLS; I’m sure this stuff isn’t really French. Eggy coated bready bread. Caused by a quick dip of fresh bread in eggy batter. Gag. Soggy bread goop. Caused by a prolonged soak of fresh bread. Crispy-edged custard-centered perfection. The secrets to French Toast are: 1: Use good quality STALE bread. 2: Swap half the egg for just EGG YOLK.

item.title: Look At All These Violent People At The Black Lives Matter Forum In Phoenix Tonight
item.description: I saw on Facebook that Black Lives Matter is a violent terrorist organization so we went to a meeting to see how bad it was. Look what we found. Phoenix Mayor Greg Stanton He wants anarchy. This panel speaker talking about educational access. She looks meek but she wants to destroy America. This lawyer answering questions about the ills of for-profit prisons and inequity in the justice system. Thug. This crusader for Native American rights who introduced herself first in Navajo then in English.

item.title: Mythical creatures I would like to be
item.description: Everybody knows the four elements are: Earth Wind Fire Water (Some ivory tower academics have proposed a ludicrously complex system with over a hundred supposed elements, an idea so absurd I see no reason to refute it.) These elements, in mixtures of various amounts, make up all around us. He imbued the elements with consciousness and in that way made life. From wind He made angels. From fire the most vile devils.

item.title: Amateur Facebook Mistakes
item.description: This is why I turn off all Facebook notifications. Commenting on an engagement announcement post. Commenting on a pregnancy announcement post. Commenting on a birth announcement post. Having a birthday.

item.title: My Work History
item.description: I can’t believe I’ve never made this list. 1989-90: Akard's True Value Hardware ‚Äî Stocker/Customer Assistance My first real job when I turned 14. Full time in the summer, part time during school. The owner was like something out of a made-for-tv remake of a Dickens novel: A beady-eyed hunched-over monster who sat in his upstairs office peering out his window at everyone in the store and counting money. I hated him.

Watching people play Pok√©mon Go around the neighborhood. Hearing people excitedly talk about Pok√©mon Go at the grocery store. Seeing people post to social media about the joy they get from Pok√©mon Go.

item.description: There are obviously a lot of good parts but this is the best part. When Harry starts calling Voldemort "Tom".

item.description: Inspired by @bjnovak. I’m a deep sleeper. What am I? Am I alive? Who am I? Why do I exist? I vaguely recall a personal history. I think I am Geoff. It's starting to come back. Yes I remember now. I am Geoff. I have a life. I have a family. I have a job. I have a personal history. I should open my eyes.

item.title: Questions That Keep Me Up at Night
item.description: Inspired by @joemurphy Am I ready to give up on this day? I mean this is it. Once I sleep this day is gone. One more day in a finite series. Tick. Tick. It wasn't a bad day. It was a great day. But isn't there more I can get from it before I discard one thirty-thousandth of my life for good Like when you get to the end of the toothpaste tube.

Brainstorming a plot point in the novel she's been working on for seven years. Cleaning her strictly cosmetic librarian glasses. Thinking about how her mom was right about a creative writing degree.

item.title: 99 Things I Love About My Wife
item.description: I love that the day we met when she was 14 she was so tan I thought she was a foreign exchange student from ... somewhere. I love that she got that tan not on the beach but working in the corn fields. Indiana. I love that she came to school one day wearing a funky dress with a peace sign incorporated into the back. I love that she sewed that dress herself.

item.title: Careers I'd Pursue If Money Wasn't An Option
item.description: @list database administrator. So I could go find all the lists with this title and change "an option" (which really doesn't make sense) to "a concern". The expression, of course, is "money is no OBJECT" but even that's wrong because we're not suggesting we'd pay any price for this career. We're just saying if we didn't care about making money, right? I mean I guess technically taking a huge pay cut could be considered paying a price, but that's stretching it.

item.title: Things Bob May Have Said to Charlotte at the End of Lost in Translation
What Happens When You Type "Google" Into Your Browser
item.description: Leaving out all the low level detail here because otherwise this would have 26,000 items. As you type your web browser consults a list it maintains of recently and frequently visited URLs and offers them as choices. It refreshes the list with each keystroke. You type "google". Before you press enter your browser has guessed that you mean "http://google.com/". It parses this URL according to a publicly defined internet standard.

item.title: The Twin Paradox
item.description: A lot of people think the "twin paradox" of relativity just means if you fly away in a space ship going close to the speed of light you'll age more slowly than your twin at home and then you'll paradoxically have twins two different ages. While perhaps surprising that isn't actually paradoxical. And it is wrong. In fact a fundamental part of "relativity" is that movement is relative. If you are in a spaceship moving away from earth at near the speed of light then.

item.title: R‚òÖ √ó f(p) √ó n(e) √ó f(l) √ó f(i) √ó f(c) √ó L
item.description: This is the Drake Equation. Sometimes pop-sci articles say it answers the question "is there intelligent life in the universe?" But that's not a very good characterization. It might be more correct to say the Drake equation helps us ask the question more precisely. After all, the only answer we have to the question "Is there intelligent life in the universe?" is: ¬Ø_(„ÉÑ)_/¬Ø Drake helps us reframe the question. It says "to answer that question here's everything we need to know.

item.title: THE STRUGGLE USED TO BE REAL...
item.description: When your sister picked up the phone in the middle of a big download and you had to start over. And her exasperated growl when she hears that modem noise. When you couldn't use the Internet (nee AOL or Prodigy) because your dad was expecting an important call. This is why the second line was invented. When your wife went to the store and you forgot to tell her you need flour.

item.title: How to Make my Favorite Chocolate Chip Cookies
item.description: Making oodles of these for @imc’s graduation open house right now. 375 F oven. Put 20 tablespoons of butter in a pan and melt it. And then brown it. Off heat stir in another stick of cold butter until it melts. Put the butter, 7 ounces of granulated sugar, 10.5 ounces of brown sugar, 2 teaspoons of salt and 2 teaspoons of vanilla extract in a bowl. Whisk. Add two eggs and two egg yolks.

Always have. And my definition of scary is broad. I HATED the queen of hearts in the Disney Alice in Wonderland when I was little, for instance. She scared me to death and she was so so so mean.

item.title: One Book, One Movie, and One Album That I Think Everyone Should Read, Watch, and Hear
item.description: This list is impossible but here goes. Book: Sophie's World by Jostein Gaarder Trying to pick a book is like trying to choose which breath was most important to you. Some were exhilarating. Some felt life saving. Some were difficult, even painful. All of them were necessary. I picked this one because it is a favorite but I don't think I've listed about it before, it is easy and approachable enough for anybody to read at almost any age, and if you're even passively interested in western thought and what it means to be human this book will thrill you.

item.title: Clouds
item.description: Ten bodies in the solar system have stable atmospheres. All of them have clouds. Venus Covered in clouds so thick we can never see the surface. Earth A contender for most beautiful clouds in the known universe. Mars Thin wispy infrequent white clouds high in the delicate atmosphere. Jupiter Look at them. Layers, bands, deep and boiling. Clouds on clouds on clouds all of contrasting colors. Beautiful. Saturn Just as complex as Jupiter but far less flashy.

item.title: 1 regret, 1 moment of pride, 1 goal, 1 dream and 1 fantasy (any way you define that)
item.description: Regret: I'm not big on regret but that's a lousy response to the question so I'll say this: That it took me so long to figure out there's nothing wrong with me and I can do and be and love anything I want. Sometimes I think the reason I like coming of age stories so much is that I spent so much of my life doing it. Pride: That I did ok with my kids.

item.title: The problem with The Grinch Who Stole Christmas
item.description: This is an apology gift to all my new followers, who I mistakenly called spammers. Forgive me. I’m not usually so cynical. Wait… The problem with The Grinch Who Stole Christmas is it's bullshit and everyone knows it. If some jerk really did steal everybody's presents and decorations and roast beast and everything else you can be sure there wouldn't be a town-wide kumbayah session come Christmas morning. First there'd be a whole lot of disappointed kids, and kids don't always handle disappointment so well.

item.description: Inspired by @amieshmamie Do you hate your birthday because of all the attention? And my family knows I like to keep it low key and they lovingly oblige. Do you think I'm a diva because I LOVE my birthday?

item.title: CROWD FUNDING PLATFORMS AND THEIR USES
item.description: Kickstarter Primarily for monetizing pie-in-the-sky ideas that can't actually be sold because they're impossible. Also useful for ideas that are possible but you don't really want to make them and just want to get money instead. Caring Bridge A currency exchange that converts sympathetic tears into US dollars. GoFundMe An outlet for narcissists to ask for money for no apparent reason. Donors Choose A republican plan for public education.

item.title: THINGS PLANET NINE WON'T DO
item.description: Crash into Earth Send a rain of hell fire (and comets!) into Earth Disrupt Earth Impact life on Earth in any way whatsoever Except that it might inspire interest in science, deepen our understanding of the solar system, and teach us new and interesting things. I guess that's an impact (yuck yuck yuck). Seriously internet relax.

item.title: LIFE'S GREATEST MYSTERY
item.description: I hate white chocolate... HATE it. I hate it so much it kind of offends me that it is called chocolate. That's like calling horse manure "brown gold". It may be brown but it definitely isn't gold. I'm not big on peppermint... I mean it's ok I guess but if the choice is between peppermint candy and any other kind I choose other. I don't really like pretzels covered in stuff.

item.title: THINGS I CAN DO WITH MY NEW IPHONE SE THAT MY OLD IPHONE 6S COULDN'T DO
item.description: Write a list one handed while my left hand is comfortably perched behind my head. Doing this right now and I'm in love. Take it out of my pocket without standing up. While in the car even! Switch to the home screen, open the camera app, flip it sideways, and snap a photo all with one hand. It's like coming home after a long trip to two handed hell.

item.title: MY BEAUTY ROUTINE
item.description: I shower every day. Twice most days in the summer. I brush my hair kind of quickly. I used to use hair spray but maybe 18 months ago I ran out as I was leaving for a trip and I realized I don't actually need it. So I stopped using it. Look how dashing my hair is anyway. I shave. I don't have much of a beard though so I skip this step a lot.

item.title: YOU HAVE 24 HOURS AND CAN DO ANYTHING YOU WANT NO RESTRICTIONS...WHAT DO YOU DO?
item.description: Sleep in til 8:00, quick shower. 8-9:00: Make breakfast for my girls. Waffles, eggs, biscuits, berries, bacon. Yes they have to be out the door before eight but this is my fantasy so I'm both sleeping in AND making a nice breakfast. The kitchen will already be tidy and clean before I start. 9-12:00: Walk to the library, sit by the windows on the 5th floor, south side, overlooking the arts district and read a book with no stress or obligations.

item.title: GOVERNMENT HACKS
item.description: I love the idea of creative workarounds to constitutional hangups. None of these are a slam dunk but they remind me that government is a complicated imaginative aggregate force of the people far more than a set of laws and that is neat. Any other cool ones? If the government is blocked from borrowing by a stonewalling congress: https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trillion_dollar_coin To eradicate the electoral college without a constitutional amendment: http://www.fairvote.org/national_popular_vote#what_is_the_national_popular_vote_plan To nominate a Supreme Court justice when the senate refuses to hold hearings:

item.title: WHAT I LOVE ABOUT MUSIC
item.description: I'm definitely not as in to music as many of you. I own a decent pile of albums (iTunes says I have about 400) and I listen to music every day while I work. But despite my father's best efforts I've never been blown away or deeply moved by the music itself. He loves classical, especially piano, and describes some of his listening experiences in almost religious terms. He is genuinely surprised that I'm not able to feel the same way.

item.title: SIGNS THIS GUY AT THE CIRCLE K IS UNDER THE INFLUENCE
item.description: He is moving his limbs strangely. He is swaying and dipping like a bad dancer. He is repeating "oh Lordy Lordy" over and over while trying to operate the slushy machine. He has a syringe with exposed needle tucked behind his ear.

item.title: THIS OR THAT: BOOK LOVERS EDITION
item.description: Inspired by @jaidub Physical Book or eBook? eBook. Unless it is not available, or the book format works better on paper. But I much prefer e. Audio book or book in hand? Both. I can't pay attention to an audio book very well so all my serious reading is book-in-hand but I do listen to audio books a lot, usually things I've already read, and especially things that benefit from good readers like Shakespeare or Joyce.

item.description: Note: I love my job. I look forward to work every morning and I love carving out some time late at night to dive deep in my work. The Appliance Guy at the dump. This guy uses a little bobcat thing to tear into washers, dryers, refrigerators and stoves. It looks like so much fun. Down side: smelly, probably not as fun after the first week. item.title: WHY I LIKE FACEBOOK
item.description: Ok you wieners. This is why I don’t just abandon Facebook. I see that my mom is active and excited about spring after a long recovery from heart surgery. Yes I talk to her but it is so nice to see what she's up to passively throughout the week. My wife cracks me up. I catch a glimpse of my sweet niece Claire in her tender moments. I keep abreast of the amazing things going on in the life of my nephew who happens to be non-verbal autistic and is an outspoken champion for acceptance and educational opportunities for all.

item.title: THINGS THAT AREN'T THE SAME THING
item.description: All words I’ve confused at one point or another. Explained poorly. Abstruse / Obtuse Hard to understand vs. unlikely to understand. Blond / Blonde and Brunet / Brunette Male/gender neutral vs. female. Does this distinction still exist? Corrected by an editor in an article I wrote once. Canvas / Canvass Canvas sail vs. canvass the neighborhood for the sale. Carat / Karat Diamonds vs. gold. Centrifugal / Centripetal Centrifugal force pushes out, centripetal force pulls in.

item.title: PAPER BOOKS I STILL OWN RANKED BY HOW LIKELY I'D BE TO GRAB THEM IF MY HOUSE CAUGHT FIRE
item.description: I got my first kindle maybe 5 or 6 years ago and began buying mostly eBooks. Then I started replacing my paper books with eBooks and slowly got rid of them all. Here are the ones I kept. The Where the Sidewalk Ends my wife (@mamiecoffey) gave me when our first child (@imc) was born. Complete with beautiful inscription. My original childhood Giving Tree. item.description: Because I just watched Eye in the Sky which was basically a (very good) two hour trolley problem. You are a switch operator and you see there are five people tied up on the tracks. The empty trolley (no passengers and unmanned) is coming and will certainly kill them all. If you throw the switch the trolley will divert down a side track and kill one person who happens to be standing on the track.

item.title: MY AMAZING DAUGHTER (@SOPHSTER)
item.description: As requested. Sophie IS amazing! One amazing thing about her is her self confidence! She is impossible to embarrass. One time when we were at Girl Scouts when she was 9 or 10 and a bunch of older girls were there I decided to embarrass her. I grabbed her and kissed her all over the face and called her my "baby boo boo". She was not embarrassed. She LOVED it. She curled up in my lap and reciprocated so ridiculously that I got very embarrassed in front of all the moms.

item.title: I'LL RESPECT YOUR WISH TO BE APART
HOW TO WORK WELL WITH SOMEONE
item.description: Assume they are competent. I know you've been burned before. So have I. Some people are terrible at what they're supposed to be doing. But everybody also deserves the benefit of the doubt. So assume their ideas are good, their experience is relevant, and their suggestions are well considered. Question your own assumptions as readily as you question theirs. Respect existing decisions. If you're coming in to an existing project, study the work they've already done and assume it was either done that way for a good reason, or at least that it is an acceptable way to do it.

item.title: WORDS THAT GET THEIR MEANING FROM A POOR INTERPRETATION OF THE FORMAL PHILOSOPHY THEY'RE NAMED AFTER
item.description: Optimist Optimism is a formal enlightenment era philosophy that supposes that the world we live in is the "best possible world" either because the laws of the universe are such that the world is the only way it could possibly be (a sort of tautological optimism) or because a benevolent force (i.e., God) controls the world and optimizes it for goodness. The latter can itself have two interpretations: All is always well from the right perspective, or more commonly that suffering is "for our own good".

item.title: THE PHONETIC SPELLING OF YOUR NAME POR FAVOR (HOW YOU PRONOUNCE)
item.description: Source: etymonline.com Jef That's it. Otherwise known as Jeff. Why is it Geoff you ask? Well, in Medieval Latin there was a name Gaufridus. It came from Old High German meaning "district of peace" (gewi + fridu). Aside: The name Frederick also comes from the Old High German fridu + reich meaning peace rule. So my name and Frederick share a common root. Anyway, the Latin Gaufridus became the Old French name Geuffroi.

item.title: DRM
item.description: I've used kindles and the kindle app for years. Whenever I buy a kindle book it always gives me the choice of which device to "deliver" it to. The list is a long mess of "iPhone #7's" and "Kindle #2's" and "Geoff's iPad" and so on. It always kind of bugged me but not enough to bother going in to whatever page on my Amazon profile to clean it out.

item.title: THE "HAN SHOT FIRST" SCENE IF GREEDO WERE REPLACED BY AN AGING JAR JAR BINKS
item.description: INT. CANTINA. Diverse strange space creatures mill about. Roguish space pirate HAN SOLO is about to leave the cantina to transport LUKE SKYWALKER, OBI WAN KENOBI and the DROIDS to ALDERAAN. JAR JAR BINKS taps Han Solo on the shoulder from behind. When Solo turns Jar Jar smiles stupidly with his tongue out and waves. Han Solo turns and walks away. JAR JAR BINKS: Ahm...EXSQUEEZEME Han Solo! Mesa be talking at you and yousa be tryin' ta leave!

item.title: WHILE WE'RE TAKING ABOUT BABY SHOWERS...
item.description: My wife threw one on Saturday. I made a killer cheese plate with three salamis, prosciutto, the best soft goat cheese I've ever tasted, cheddar for weenies, and a few other cheeses, sourdough bread, olives and cornichons (I have no idea how you spell that... @Lisa_Fav?), Brazil nuts and pistachios, halved dried figs and dried sour cherries, and sour cherry jam. It was beautiful. And I made a killer cheesy artichoke spinach dip with triangles of French bread drizzled with olive oil and toasted.

She can make a best friend in the elevator, she makes killer lasagna, she always makes something special for each kid when we visit, and she is fiercely loyal to my dad. What I'm saying is she is üíØ. My big sister.

item.title: TOLERABLE CHILDREN'S MUSIC
item.description: There’s a period of time when your kids are little enough that you need some kid-friendly music to entertain them in the car. Unfortunately most children’s music is insufferable. Here are some good albums. Smithsonian Folkways Children's Music Collection / Various This whole album is fun, beautiful, and historically significant. American folk music with a kid friendly focus. A mix of greats like Pete Seeger, Ella Jenkins, Jean Ritchie and Woody Guthrie.

item.title: NPR IN THE CAR
item.description: cc @npr I've heard the answer to a million puzzlers and the question to a million more but only a few times have I heard them both together. Sitting in the grocery store parking lot with the car running for 15 minutes. Sitting in the driveway in the dark with the car off dumbstruck by the sincerity of Maurice Sendak's final interview with Terry Gross. Pledge drive? Ugh. How do I even change stations on this radio I have no idea.

item.description: In which I share with you all what a happy day this is. This is @sophster and her very special friend Maia when they were in 4th grade. Here's another one with Sophia actually smiling. Maia always takes beautiful pictures with a big smile. Sophia not so much. Here she is up close. They are so close they are practically sisters. They were best buddies from 4th through 6th grade. But they always knew Maia's family would move away after sixth grade.

item.title: PHASES OF A SCHOOL PARENT MEETING
item.description: The teachers awkwardly alternating who's speaking phase. The slight head nod at the people you only ever see at parent meetings and have never actually talked to phase. The stopping repeatedly to hand papers to late comers phase. The lame joke phase. The gingery trying to explain some perfectly reasonable policy without offending a hypersensitive parent phase. The parents ask questions that were just answered phase. The parents upstage one another with irrationally aggressive concern for their special snowflake phase.

item.title: FICTIONAL WOMEN I WOULD FOR SURE DATE
item.description: Inspired by @kcupcaker. It’s not lost on me the fact that none of these women would be particularly interested in an introverted homebody like me :) Elizabeth Bennett Straight up in love with her. Smart, independent, determined, brave, self aware. Beatrice from Much Ado about Nothing Funny, witty, passionate, complicated. Eponine Granted she's not in the best shape, health wise. Oh and she's dead. But she will always be special to me because she overcame so much for love and let it go anyway.

item.title: A Brief History of the GIF
item.description: This list is so dumb. "GIF" stands for "Graphic Interchange Format". It is a de facto standard for images released by CompuServe in 1987. Remember CompuServe? Of course you don't. It is a really old online service kind of like America Online but older. But you all don't remember that either. It's like pre-Internet online shopping and social media with a Linux command line. Anyway, it's old. Other computery things that came out in 1987 include:

item.title: READING IN TO HARPER LEE
item.description: From Go Set a Watchman: "If you did not want much, there was plenty." I'm not sure if that was meant to be an epicurean admonishment to not want so much, or a dig at the rural south for not having much to offer.. ...but I choose the former interpretation. And say thank you to Harper Lee for giving us so much in so few volumes.

"Vanity of vanities, saith the Preacher, vanity of vanities; all is vanity. What profit hath a man of all his labour which he taketh under the sun? One generation passeth away, and another generation cometh: but the earth abideth for ever. ‚Ä¶ All the rivers run into the sea; yet the sea is not full; unto the place from whence the rivers come, thither they return again.

item.title: NAMES FOR THINGS THAT NEED NAMES
item.description: Some of these are real. Some are my proposals. Canadian Standoff When you cross paths with someone and you step right and they step right and then you step left and they step left and then you chuckle awkwardly and you both say "you go ahead" and then you both say "sorry" and eventually sort of awkwardly sort it out. Battery Fatigue When you consciously decide not to buy something only because it is one more thing you'll have to plug in every night.

item.title: THINGS I DO THAT CAUSE BOOKISH PEOPLE TO DOUBT MY COMMITMENT TO THE CAUSE
item.description: Send all my paper books to goodwill and switch to almost 100% eBooks. I like reading eBooks so much better unless pictures or layout are important to the book. Forget the title of books and the names of authors all the time. Have to ask what "TBR" means when I attend a bookish conference thing in New York with @ChrisK. Related: Avoid keeping a TBR list. Feel completely overwhelmed by shelves full of books.

item.title: HOW TO BE ME IN FIVE EASY STEPS
item.description: Inspired by @maggieannre Kill me. I'd prefer you do this quickly and painlessly but that isn't strictly necessary. Carefully study my proportions. Using advanced 3D Printing technology, manufacture a Geoff-suit. Insinuate yourself into my family and life. Whenever the lights dim and the opening flourish starts when you're watching a movie, lean over to the person next to you and say quietly and nervously, "I'm scared. Are you scared?" This will 100% convince any member of my family that you are really me and go a long way toward glossing over the fact that you didn't know their names or where the bathroom was in our house.

item.title: MIND BENDING RELATIVE TIME LINES.
item.description: I’m not sure if these are really “mind bending”. Maybe I should have said “somewhat interesting”. But anyway these all interested me! Dinosaurs ruled the earth for a very very long time. Modern humans have existed for at least 200,000 years and maybe as long as a million years. Dinosaurs first appeared 232 million years ago and "disappeared" (if you ignore birds) 65 million years ago. I know this will come as a shock to you but The Land Before Time was highly inaccurate.

item.title: PROPOSED NAMES FOR PLANET NINE
item.description: Proserpine (Persephone to the Greeks) This is my number one: She inhabits the underworld which fits a body so deep in the dark. Proserpine was stolen into the underworld and there is some thought that Planet Nine was kicked into the outer solar system early in its formation. She is often associated with the coming forth and withdrawal of seasons which has a nice symmetry with Planet Nine's supposed highly eccentric orbit.

Everything in this “recipe” can be adjusted/swapped/augmented in a million ways which is one of the things that makes tacos so wonderful. üåÆüåÆüåÆ Corn tortillas, toasted in a dry pan to warm them up and make them a little toasty. I prefer corn but hey I love soft tacos on four tortillas too, and I love crispy tacos too.

item.title: HOW TO MAKE YOUR TACOS 62% BETTER
item.description: This is how you make Cebolla en Escabeche (sometimes called Cebollita), the beautiful, super simple, mild “pickled” red onion they serve at street side taco stands in Mexico. Cut a red onion in half, slice it thin, and put it in a bowl. Pour boiling water to cover the onion. Count to ten, then immediately drain off the water. This makes the onions a bit softer and takes a bit of the edge off.

item.title: CARDINAL SINS OF NEWS SITE DESIGN

item.title: CHECK YOURSELF WITH THE FUNDAMENTAL ATTRIBUTION ERROR
item.description: This was one of the most eye opening things I ever learned. The "Fundamental Attribution Error" is a concept in social psychology. It is the tendency for people to attribute behavior in others to *character* rather than to external factors. It does not apply to how we judge our *own* behavior. And possibly some of the behaviors of those very close to us in some situations. But left unchecked it applies to our judgement of everyone else.

item.title: IF THE POWERBALL DOUBLES ONE MORE TIME...

item.title: LAST DITCH WIZARD DUELING MOVES
HOW TO BE BRAVE IN SEVEN EASY STEPS
item.description: Be certain. Nothing undermines courage like uncertainty. So if there's any doubt, do your analysis and make sure you know you want to do this. Be precise. Know exactly what you want. Not vaguely. Not the minimum. Exactly what you want to do. Be calm. Remember to breathe. But not too fast. Count your breaths if you have to. Take the first step. Just the first step. The time for thinking ahead is over and now it's time to focus on one step at a time.

item.title: WOMEN OF THE COMPUTATION REVOLUTION
item.description: People in my generation lived right through what will, when my great grand children study history in school, be taught the way we all learned about the “Industrial Revolution”. It took its first baby steps in the 1940s, was in full swing in the 1970s, and is in its third wave today. Women have been and continue to be instrumental in this change. Ada Lovelace ~ 1815 ‚Äì1852 This brilliant 19th century mathematician is credited as the world's first computer programmer even though she died a hundred years before the first real computers.

These two lived side by side on the shelf when we got married. 2000: We bought it on DVD when we got a DVD player. [2010: My DVD player died and I didn't really want to deal with disks anymore anyway so I ripped a few of my favorite DVDs, including this one, and put them on my network backup drive.

item.title: HOW TO HANDLE A 4-WAY STOP
item.description: üöóüöïüöôüöê If you're first. Yay! Go ahead and go. If you're second. Wait for the first person. Then you get to go! If you're third. Wait for the first person. Then assert your dominance by rolling forward a few inches while the second person goes. Then you get to go! If you're fourth. Wait for the first to go. Then the guy who is third will go in front of the guy who is second.

item.title: HOW TO MAKE PERFECT OATMEAL
item.description: My daughter @sophster calls this “special oatmeal” and it is one of her favorite foods. It is creamy, oaty, and has a silky texture. Melt a couple tablespoons of butter in a pot on medium heat. Add a cup of steel cut oats to the butter. I assume this recipe won't work well with rolled oats but I've never tried. Toast the oats in the butter for a few minutes.

item.title: THE TWENTY BEST MOMENTS IN STAR WARS
GLOBAL EXTINCTIONS, RANKEDüìÇ
item.description: Merry #draftmas. Not sure why I never published this one. I think I was trying to give it a theme or something and abandoned it. Permian-Triassic Extinction Event ~ 252 million years ago Otherwise known as the "Great Dying" this is the big one. Over some thousands of years, 96% of marine species and 75% of the terrestrial species went extinct. Evolution would require up to ten million years to re-establish previous levels of biodiversity.

item.title: HOW TO SMOKE A PORK SHOULDER
item.description: Pork Shoulder (sometimes called Pork Butt) is a great first-time “big” thing to smoke because it is delicious, special, and very forgiving. If you have a smoker or have access to one, this is easy, fun, delicious, and people will think you’re amazing üíÖüèΩ Get some meat Lots of recipes and blogs claim a bone-in shoulder has better flavor. I once made three shoulders at once for a party and happened to have one bone-in and two boneless and I'm here to tell you it doesn't really matter.

item.title: E.B. WHITE IS LIKE MY HERO
NEVER NOT GREAT
item.description: An abridged list because I’m sure I would come up with five or six more if I tried. Eddie Redmayne This guy blows me away every time I see him. It is hard to believe one person can become so many things so perfectly. The best singer in Les Mis and the only good thing about Jupiter Rising. From the preview, his performance in The Danish Girl looks like it will be staggeringly good.

item.title: I KILLED A BIRD
item.description: Once when I was 13 or 14 a bird came down our chimney. It was in the cold fireplace behind the closed glass doors. The fireplace had a gas starter. You could turn a knob and flames would light the logs. My father is a smart man. He finished premed in 3 years and had a long career as a very successful anesthesiologist, department chief, and hospital administrator. But he's not a smart man if you know what I mean.

item.title: ALL THESE LISTS ABOUT CHILDHOOD SMELLS‚Ä¶
item.description: They are lovely. They remind me of the beautiful passage from Proust when as a grown man his mother offered him tea and a Madeline cookie and he sought to understand the pleasant feeling it elicited. The whole passage is beautiful but here’s the part about the recovered memories. Inspired by people inspired by @ChrisK. And suddenly the memory revealed itself. The taste was that of the little piece of madeleine which on Sunday mornings at Combray (because on those mornings I did not go out before mass), when I went to say good morning to her in her bedroom, my aunt L√©onie used to give me, dipping it first in her own cup of tea or tisane.

item.title: BIRTHDAY "CAKES" FOR MY FAMILY
item.description: I love to bake… Sophia always asks for pineapple upside down cake. So delicious and perfect for December. Isabel (@imc) has a summer birthday and usually wants fresh berry tart with pastry cream. Delicious AND beautiful. Her birthday is in July so we usually have a red/white/blue thing going on with blanched blueberries and strawberries or raspberries. My wife is trickier. Her tastes vary. Sometimes pumpkin cheesecake. Sometimes flourless chocolate cake.

item.description: This is what it means when I click Like. "I really like this" ‚Äî 5% "I really like someone else's comment but I feel strangely guilty clicking like on hers and ignoring yours" ‚Äî 45% Like! ... [pause] ... *sigh* ... Like like like like like. "This conversation is now over" ‚Äî 45% Yeah I'm not replying again. Like. "You seem lonely and this post at least isn't offensive" ‚Äî 5%

item.title: TWO CATS: A STUDY IN CONTRASTING PERSONALITIES
item.description: This is Rosencrantz. He is five months old. He has been running around the house like a madman since we brought him home 18 hours ago. He has jumped in my lap, over-consumed water and regurgitated it on the floor, and made a hilarious failed attempt at jumping up to the table. He occasionally overestimates the traction of the wood floor and I hear him skittling across the hall and into the wall.

item.title: HONEST GENDER ISSUES QUESTION
item.description: Does it make sense to have separate awards categories for male and female actors? Just dawned on me it is maybe kind of weird. But I don't know. I'm poorly educated on gender issues. Has a transgender actor even been nominated for an Oscar or whatever?

item.title: THINGS BARBERS ALWAYS OVERESTIMATE
item.description: Their ability to make my hair lay flat. This has happened since I was a little boy. "Can I put some gel in it?" "More power to you man. I wish you luck." I was basically Harry Potter. Minus the wand, courage, and hot friend. But with the hair and hand-me-down clothes. Expecto patronum.

item.title: I'LL HAVE "THE SALLY"
item.description: Salad Chef salad with the oil and vinegar on the side. Pie Apple pie a la mode. But I'd like the pie heated. And I don't want the ice cream on top, I want it on the side. And I'd like strawberry instead of vanilla if you have it. If not then no ice cream, just whipped cream. But only if it's real. If it's out of a can then nothing.

item.title: THE FIVE BEST THINGS IN MY LIFE RIGHT NOW

But in the interest of space I shall combine. In the words of Seymour from Ghost World (see #5!) “My top five interests? I’d have to put traditional jazz, blues, and then ragtime at the top of the list‚Ä¶” My Family

item.description: Interviewing a candidate at work with my coworkers makes me more nervous than interviewing for a job. Way more. Being the interviewee doesn't make me nervous at all but I stress so much about interviewing someone. I think this is just because I'm very confident in my profession but never claimed to be a competent interviewer. Speaking in church before 150 people makes me more nervous than speaking in a conference in front of 1000 people.

item.title: THERE ARE A LOT OF PHOTONS
item.description: I think about this sometimes. A reasonable guess of the number of atoms in the universe is around 4e79. That's a very big number. There are about a billion times more photons than atoms. But the universe is big and this is hard to visualize. I like to think of it this way‚Ä¶ Have you ever looked up at Saturn in the night sky? It is a brilliant solid golden star, very beautiful.

item.description: I am the greatest dad in the world. Because she loves it and she's been working super hard lately and deserves a comfort food treat. I am the worst dad on the world. Because it is packaged convenience food and I'm poisoning my family. Poo-tee-weet.

item.title: THE MEANING OF LIFE IN FIVE BULLET POINTS, ACCORDING TO ME
item.description: Inspired by @ChrisK I want to be happy. We are all of us lost sometimes, uncertain sometimes, and we try to have faith in something, whatever it may be, and hope our lives have meaning. But any true meaning is hard to come by. Whatever I think though, what always gives me the deepest happiness is to be a little less selfish for a time. Paradoxically, forgetting yourself and giving to someone else makes YOU feel better.

item.title: WHY NERDY GIRLS ARE SEXIER
item.description: This was a hard list request. I rethought my approach three times and I’m still not sure I’m making the case correctly. But here you go! Because passionate interests are infectious. Let your nerd flag fly because I love that you love the world so much and it makes me see things in a new way. Because eventually the smiling and nodding comes to an end and it's time to talk.

item.title: DIFFERENT WAYS TO PRONOUNCE YOUR NAME
item.description: I’m interpreting this as ways people have pronounced my name. When I was a kid people seemed to universally be confused by my name but now almost everyone gets it right. I think I have Geoffrey the Giraffe to thank for that. Jeff The right way. Goff Yeah I don't know. Jee-off By far the most common. Joff A time or two. Jee-Oaf Only my friend calls me this. Jah-fray

item.description: The time in second grade when I just really wanted to kiss her and my teacher taught me about boundaries. That time in fourth grade when Carrie said I was really funny and I fell madly in love with her because of it. The time in fifth grade when Tiffany informed me we were going together for the day. And I was expected to kiss her in the back field at recess.

item.title: OBJECTIVE REASONS TO FIND GRITS GOOD
item.description: Grits, like all grain-based hot cereals, are objectively good. They are warm and comforting. People objectively like comfort. They are versatile. Soft or firm, sweet or savory, creamy, fried, spicy, mild, cheesy‚Ä¶grits don't care. People objectively like versatility. They are a good friend to less outgoing foods. I know what you're thinking: smoked brisket is amazing. But it's not the kind of thing to draw attention to itself. Grits can nestle up next to them and say "I'm here for you, and I won't take away from you.

item.title: SOME OF MY FAVORITE LITERARY CONCEITS
item.description: The all caps dialog of Owen Meany Cormac McCarthy's spare punctuation around ornate sentences The thread of narration in American Pastoral It could be considered a spoiler I guess so I won't say exactly what I mean but the way the narration is structured around this story is one of the most expertly executed things I've ever read. Complex narration in Frankenstein The poetic repetition of The Odyssey Meta fiction in Vonnegut's work

item.title: TODDLER THOUGHTS: HALLOWEEN
item.description: You haven’t lived til you’ve taken a toddler on her first Halloween trick-or-treat outing. Oh @imc I remember it like it was yesterday. Mom looks weird. Dad looks weird. Wait what are they putting on me? This is not a onesie. This is not comfortable. Holy heck she's drawing on my face. [cries] Glad that's over. Definitely bath time now. Then stories. Then the part where they try to make me sleep.

item.title: SOME FUN PARADOXES, RANKED
item.description: Zeno's Tortoise Paradox Hercules challenges a tortoise to a foot race. Seeing as he is Hercules he gives the tortoise a 100 yard head start. The race begins with the tortoise walking slowly and Hercules in an all out sprint. Soon Hercules has run 100 yards and reached the tortoise's starting point. But by now the tortoise has walked ahead some. Hercules must now catch up to that point. When he does, obviously the tortoise has walked further still.

item.title: IN WHICH MY DAUGHTER SOPHIA CONFESSES TO GROSS EARLY CHILDHOOD MISUNDERSTANDING
item.description: You know the movie The Emperor’s New Groove? My girls loved the movie when they were little. I was talking to Sophie today (she’s 13 now) and she made these related confessions… First, she thought the man who "threw off the Emperor's groove" in this scene was a woman. Yeah I don't know... Second, in this scene she thought Pacha handed him his cell phone. In 13th century Central America. That he then put on his foot.

item.title: THINGS THAT AMAZE ME
item.description: You can type anything into Google and it can show you all the web pages in the world that mention it ranked quite well by relevance. In milliseconds. From California. There are little molecular machines in each of the billions of cells in your body unzipping your DNA, transcribing it, duplicating it, correcting errors, and stitching it back together again. Right now. The act of opening this list caused an unimaginably long cascade of micro-instructions to be executed by a tiny solid state Turing machine inside your iPhone across hundreds of coordinated pieces of software.

item.title: WORDS YOU PEOPLE USE
item.description: Squad This is apparently not just cheerleaders although it is maybe kind of cheerleaders. Jam Not, apparently, fruit spread. Fleek Literally no idea. Basic I think it kind of means what it means but I also think it maybe means something else.

item.title: HOW TO LOVE (ALMOST) ANYBODY IN FOUR EASY STEPS
item.description: Before you start ask yourself, out of all the people in the world, how many are good enough? I don’t mean do calculus, or study statistics. I’m asking philosophically. What does it mean, fundamentally, if people‚Äîso far as we know the only things in the universe to which goodness really applies‚Äîaren’t mostly good enough for you? Now you’re ready‚Ä¶ Step 1: Forgive There are exceptions of course. But for the most part you can simply let it go.

item.title: MAGIC NUMBERS, RANKED
item.description: This may be the dumbest nerdiest list I’ve ever made. It embarrasses me. Fast Inverse Square Root ~ 0x5f3759df The most magical of all magic numbers. Google if you're curious but probably only if you're also a programmer. Avogadro's Number ~ 6.02e23 Just an all around fascinating number. I mean really, heavy gas, light gas, doesn't matter! It's always the same. Surprising and cool. Of course now that I think about it, the fact that it is the same is probably what makes it possible for a gas to be "heavy" in the first place.

item.title: MEDICAL SCIENCE IS THE REASON I'M HERE
item.description: I’ll put the people I love. You add you! Me: hospitalized with serious asthma at age 3 My brother: abscessed appendix at age 14, sub-dural hematoma at age 40 My wife: abscessed appendix at age 30 My mother: appendicitis at age 10, mitral valve replacement at age 70 My brother in law: lymphoma at age 35 My brother in law: two broken vertebrae in the neck My business partner: spinal cord injury, severe internal bleeding, multiple organ failure

item.title: JUST THE GOOD PARTS
item.description: Examples of good things stripped of the inessential to reveal their truest value. Caramel The overt richness of butter and sugar freed from the conformist structures of flour-based baking. Halloween They unbridled joy of holiday celebration unburdened by moral imperative. Raclette Melted cheese by itself, which is all we really want, elevated from gaucherie by a French sounding name. Ooh la la so sophisticated! The American Flag Patriotic assertion of national pride unconflicted by ‚Ä¶ well ‚Ä¶ almost everything right now.

item.title: ROM COMS WORTH WATCHING
item.description: I love a good romantic comedy but most of them aren’t very good. I’m no expert but to me this is how the genre family tree looks. Hop on the 400 year romantic comedy train. Much Ado About Nothing ~ 1598 This play is ostensibly a retelling of a classic story of love and deception, but the Beatrice/Benedict "subplot" is, as far as we know, Shakespeare's invention. And really it is the main plot: the one we are most invested in, the one into which Shakespeare puts his theatrical genius, and perhaps the original modern romantic comedy.

item.title: BOOKS THAT ARE REALLY GOOD AND CULTURALLY MERITORIOUS, BUT ALSO NOT TERRIBLY DIFFICULT TO GET IN TO
item.description: Inspired by @hels, highly opinionated. Meant to be an open list with just a couple entries but I got carried away. American Pastoral by Philip Roth Roth is widely regarded as one of the great modern American novelists and this book is thoroughly engrossing and highly relevant to fractured American culture. The Diary of a Young Girl by Anne Frank It is impossible not to love this book. Funny, moving, intimate, and breathtakingly sad.

item.description: Not much room for debate here people. Hoth Leia Bespin Leia Endor Leia New York Leia Yavin Leia Tatooine Leia Death Star Leia The classic but let's be honest: Pretty stupid looking. Stupid Ewok Leia Stupid Ewoks can even ruin Leia.

item.title: HAPPY BIRTHDAY @EVANP
item.description: Happy birthday Evan Pompodou! I hope you have a wonderful day Evan Primrose! You're a swell guy Evan Pomonomino! It's been fun listing with you Evan Pumpernickel! Hope to meet you some day Evan Pilkington! Aside... ...How do you say your name?

item.title: WHY THE ROSEATE SPOONBILL WILL ALWAYS BE MY FAVORITE BIRD: A REMEMBRANCE
item.description: This is a Roseate Spoonbill. This is my dad today. Our story takes place many years ago. But now, as then, he is a man of great passions. When I was 14 we took a trip to Sanibel Island in Florida. My sisters were in college so it was just mom, dad, my brother and I. One day we decided to visit a nature preserve. We learned that it was a breeding ground for the endangered Roseate Spoonbill.

item.title: SOPHIA'S BIG (LITTLE) DEBUT
item.description: Sophie landed the part of Lieutenant Ward of the 17th Precinct in a local youth theater production of Annie. She worked hard for weeks and had the time of her life. She was smiling from ear to ear after the first show. First scene! Like a boss Busted Hey there she is back there! And, take a bow!

item.title: MOVIES THAT GIVE ME THAT SLIGHT THROAT LUMPY FEELING OFTEN ASSOCIATED WITH CRYING (NO TEARS üôÖüèº)
item.description: In order from least to most embarrassing. Lost in Translation When Charlotte calls Lauren and they don't connect. The Merchant of Venice (The Al Pacino version) When Shylock, having been humiliated and fined, then has his faith and community stripped away. Silver Linings Playbook When Pat's father says "when life reaches out with a moment like this it's a sin if you don't reach back." Silver Linings Playbook When Tiffany asks, "You love me?

item.description: Look: Trouble on the Homefront Getting an MRI Down the drain Hoping I bump in to @TheBianca IRL Operating heavy machinery Strange dry skin patch on my finger was driving me nuts ... WHICH IS IT?!

Maybe some day I'll do a list called "MOVIES THAT MADE ME GET THAT SLIGHT THROAT LUMPY FEELING OFTEN ASSOCIATED WITH CRYING (ALTHOUGH I STRESS THERE WERE NO ACTUAL TEARS AND CERTAINLY NO GASPING OR SNOT-DRIPPING)"

The foot shot again This random number generator sucks. This gem of a selfie When I woke up this morning I thought to myself "I sure hope everyone on List App sees this picture of me some day."

item.title: REASONS LIST APP NEEDS DIRECT MESSAGING
item.description: I want to direct message @TheBianca I need to direct message @TheBianca I think she is amazing And we could totally be best friends (Or more üò≥) But I have no way to tell her Because List App has no direct messaging I'd even consider unfollowing @sally and/or @mallofamanda to make her happy (Don't tell them I said that.) Bianca you're the coolest

item.title: WORLD TEACHER'S DAY: THE TEACHERS THAT IMPACTED ME THE MOST
item.description: Inspired by @Nicholas I should probably just apologize. In grade order. Sorry Mrs. Kanull For pulling over the cabinet and spilling its contents all over the floor. Sorry Mrs. Art Techer For giving you the middle finger through the window and then denying it when someone told on me. Sorry Mrs. Gray For pretending to drop my crayon and crawling around my desk like a dog. Sorry Mrs. Hobson For my handwriting.

item.title: REASONS I STILL FAVOR THE DEATH PENALTY
item.description: (Yes I’m sitting on the toilet. Deal with it.) These super-stiff toilet paper rolls earn the designer life in prison. This ridiculously thin toilet paper earns the manufacturer life in prison. Use them together? LETHAL INJECTION for whoever operates the bathroom.

item.title: 10 Most Influential Albums in My Life
item.description: Stand By Me Soundtrack This was the first record I owned myself with my brand new record player so I could listen to what I wanted in my room. U2 Joshua Tree The first album I bought with my own money and one I listened to from about 12 years old right up to the present day. Still great. Bob Dylan's Greatest Hits It's a little embarrassing to put a "greatest hits" album on here but this was my intro to Dylan in high school which makes it a very big deal.

item.title: WHY CAN'T I COMMENT ON @MAYA'S LISTS
item.description: Does this mean I'm blocked? It's ok if I am. No hard feelings. But like there's also someone named @olive that I can't see at all so I assumed that is what happens when you're blocked. I can see Maya's lovely lists but I just don't get a comment button. Is there a setting that only allows comments from someone who follows you? Maybe @maya has it set up that way?

item.title: IS ELON MUSK A SUPERVILLAIN: EVIDENCE FOR AND AGAINST
item.description: FOR: Apparently has access to unlimited nuclear bombs and the means to deliver them anywhere in the inner solar system. AGAINST: Getting a little chubby. FOR: Technological prowess seems to far surpass others. AGAINST: Uses that prowess to make fast cars and batteries. FOR: Billionaire AGAINST: Made fortune from something with "Pal" in the name. FOR: Named "Elon" AGAINST: Named "Musk" FOR: Has his fingers in diverse industries suitable for comprehensive take-over-the-world activities

item.title: EWOKS: PROS AND CONS (MOSTLY CONS)
item.description: PRO: Not jar jar binks CON: obviously just human children and little people wearing elaborate PJs PRO: one of them dies a smokey death and the noise his buddy makes is hilarious CON: only one of them dies a smokey death PRO: finally convince Leia to let her hair down a bit CON: Leia is way hotter with her hair up PRO: Helped the rebels destroy the shield generator

item.title: TOP TEN WAYS I HAVE BROKEN MY BONES OR INJURED MYSELF ACCORDING TO MY TEEN DAUGHTER, SOPHIA, RANKED
item.description: My skull. I cracked my skull when I was a year old by climbing up the drawer handles. Breaking my foot by climbing up 15 feet in the air and then jumping down. Broke my arm when I was two when I was swinging on a swing and flew off. Jumping on the trampoline and I did a flip but I flipped right off and landed on my back and sprained my finger.

item.title: GOODNIGHT SKY
item.description: A dystopian novel-list inspired by @ErinFlaherty in which she and @sky press on. The sun set cold in the north, a distant blue pebble in the otherwise featureless gray sky. She blew into her hands and rubbed them together. Her skin was chapped and cracking. - It won't be much longer. - I don't suppose so. - Not sure what time will mean anymore when we're down there. They unloaded their makeshift pack.

item.title: STAR WARS FILMS RANKED
item.description: Yeah I know this is unoriginal and a pot shot. The Empire Strikes Back A New Hope Return of the Jedi [placeholder for the new one] One of the crappy ones Another of the unmemorable bore-fests Whichever of the plotless feces-laden prequels is left

item.title: THE 10 MOST IMPORTANT BOOKS IN THE WORLD ACCORDING TO MY TEENAGE DAUGHTER, ISABEL, RANKED
item.description: Requested by @ChrisK (She said “this is not in the world, this is in the western tradition because I don’t know any books in the world. Make sure you edit it to say that.”) Plato's Republic The Bible Euclid's Elements The Illiad Herodotus or Thucydides "I'm not sure which." My Antonia (Paused here, mumbled to herself, said she wanted to think of something from Ancient Rome but couldn't remember, maybe Horace or Caesar's De Bello Gallico.

item.title: THOUGHTS AS I TRY TO FIND THE EMERGENCY ROOM OF THIS HOSPITAL FROM THE PARKING GARAGE
item.description: I'm glad I'm not dying. Wow, I'm glad I'm not hurt at all. I should have said yes to the guy in the golf cart when he offered me a ride. I should have brought water. Eh, I could use the exercise. Did I like eat Apollo's sacred cattle or something? Will I ever see my Penelope‚Ä¶er I mean my wife again. That looks like an emergency room. But I've read about this before.

item.title: CONFESSION TIME
item.description: I didn't invite any of you to my bar mitzva On a technicality; I'm no Bianca Zimmer. I went to a b'not mitzvah once. The ceremony part, not the the party part. It was lovely. I figured out the "Moshe" means "Moses" be listening and reading along and was proud of myself. I secretly think I would adore the "bear don't eat my kayak" lady if I knew her in real life.

item.title: REASONS I HAVEN'T LISTED LATELY
item.description: Sophia's in a play and has rehearsal in Scottsdale Monday-Thursday and I take her two days a week. Zoom zoom to the school at 3:00 to pick her up, zoom home, eat, homework, zoom to Scottsdale, drop her off, zoom to restaurant with wifi, work for 2 hours 45 minutes, zoom to pick her up, zoom home. Home by 9:00. Zoom zoom. Isabel is in a school play. Practice practice.

item.description: The Emmys The Oscars Local sporting events

item.description: Side note: I üíó my Apple Watch. Finally has an exercise category for "going to Costco". Subtle warning on the wrist when approaching terrorists or teenage nerds. Now fully supports my religious freedom. 20% increase in smugness. Automatically logs prostate function. When in a room with three or more Apple watches, they will all begin to chirp affectionately. $17,000 solid gold version now includes customizable Feel The Bern themed watch face.

item.description: Note: Edward is the lion in this version. A metaphorical lion monster. The Lion, The Witch, and The Awakening [the end]

item.title: HOW TO READ A LIST
item.description: Read the list title on the feed. Check the lister's name. If it is like @rachaelray or whatever then be like wow it's Rachel Ray or whatever that's pretty neat. If it is @ChrisK save it for when you have time to process a lot. If it is another name you recognize open the list. Read the first item. Read the title and description. Read the second item. Read the last item.

item.title: MOVIES I WILL ALWAYS STOP FLIPPING CHANNELS TO WATCH
item.description: Inspired by @sarahdessen What the heck is a "channel"? Just kidding but seriously you guys know about Netflix and HBO go and iTunes and all that stuff right? (Smug emoji)

item.title: MY IDEAL MAKEOVER
item.description: If I could control my appearance with no limitations. Come on science make these happen. Sideshow Bob's devil-may-care hair. Adrien Brody's no-nonsense nose. Kelly Clarkson's happy cry face. Ira Glass's eye glasses. Stephen Colbert's subtle smirk. Kristin Wiig's long strong lady legs.
