item.description: http://53eig.ht/1L6QSm3 Or do they!? Or is he?! Or is he!? Or are they!? Or is it!? Or is she!?

item.title: HOW TO PERFORM THE HEIMLICH MANEUVER ON A STRANGER WHO IS NOT CHOKING
item.description: This is something I do a lot of. Identify an unsuspecting stranger. Preferably someone who looks like they might be socially awkward or not interested in interaction. Run to your target and exclaim "ARE YOU OK?!" Ideally the person will look at you surprised and say nothing. Spread your arms wide and demand the person be given "some space". Do this even if there is nobody around. Put your shoulders back and say "don't worry, I read about this on @wikiHow.

item.title: MY FAVORITE HOLIDAY üëØ
item.description: #7 of my last minute sharing week dump. Inspired by @ChrisK Thanksgiving is my favorite holiday. I didn't have to think about this. It always has been. I love the sentiment. A holiday devoted to thankfulness for the bounty of life is something that resonates with me a lot. I love food. Especially comfort food. And desserts. I love cooking for my family. I make thanksgiving dinner because it is like meditative joy for me.

item.title: THINGS I DON'T LIKE KNOWING ABOUT MYSELF ?
item.description: #6 of my last minute sharing week dump. Inspired by @ChrisK I treat men and women differently. I try not to but I do. I'm more inclined to drop what I'm doing and help a woman. This is probably patronizing and certainly rooted in inaccurate culturally-ingrained assumptions about capability and capacity to deal. I'm also more likely to talk to a woman, to open up to a woman, to have a sincere conversation with a woman, and to listen to a woman.

item.title: WHERE I WOULD GO IF I COULD TIME TRAVEL?
item.description: #4 of my last minute sharing week dump. Inspired by @ChrisK 1978 Mesa Arizona Because nothing would make me happier than seeing my wife as a toddler being adorable. The very distant future Because I want to know about our future, what becomes of us. Because it is more unknowable than the past. Because we will learn things in the next, say, 1,000 years and I'll never know them and that makes me a little sad.

item.title: PARALLEL UNIVERSES
item.description: The one where Kim Davis is a fundamentalist Mormon customs official who won't allow coffee into the country. The one where Kim Davis is a fundamentalist naturalist game and fish official who refuses to issue hunting licenses to anyone who wants to kill animals. The one where Kim Davis is a fundamentalist Jewish labor department official who refuses to e-verify women for employment. The one where Kim Davis is a fundamentalist pastafarian OSHA official who refuses to certify non-colander head protection.

item.title: THINGS ON MY MESSY DESK RIGHT NOW
item.description: I’m sure this is very inspiring for all you little people. This Kurt Vonnegut finger puppet my daughter gave me a few years ago. This stays magneted to my screen. This "Isabel's birthday star" craft thing my other daughter made for me years ago. The brilliant star Sirius sometimes seems to flicker different colors, and one night when my girls were small we though it looked red, white, and blue. These are Isabel's "birthday colors" because she was born on July 10 and always associated her birthday with US Independence Day.

item.title: THINGS TO ADD TO RICE KRISPY TREATS TO MAKE THEM üíØ
item.description: This is a very short list because Rice Krispy treats are near-perfect for what they are: The treat with the highest yum:easy ratio on earth. 50% more butter than the recipe says My personal recipe is a stick of butter and one and a half bags of large marshmallows. This makes them softer and richer. If that half-bag annoys you like it does me then IT SOUNDS LIKE YOU NEED TO MAKE TWO BATCHES.

item.title: FAVORITE WEB SITES
item.description: etymonline.com üîó The Online Etymology Dictionary I look stuff up here all the time because it is endlessly fascinating. Like just now I looked up "story" after reading @THEToughCookie's list because I wondered why we call floors of a building a "story" and of course the answer was neat. xkcd.com üîó xkcd The only web comic I read (since Home Star Runner is no more). Definitely geeky, often geared toward programmers and engineers, occasionally over my head but almost always funny.

item.title: ZOMBIE APOCALYPSE PREPAREDNESS RANKED
item.description: Salt Lake City I think 80 percent of Utahns have weapons buried in the back yard and stockpiles of food in the house. The state even has a giant granite mountain panic room. Add to that a population of Eagle Scouts and a wicked army of stay at home moms and you have, bar none, the safest place in the country if the world is overrun with ravaging bands of mindless monsters.

item.title: THINGS I SUCK AT
item.description: Obligatory follow up to my previous list. Hearing For a year we thought I had "cookie bite syndrome" congenital hearing loss. Then it went away. It comes and goes and drives my poor wife crazy. What? What? Sorry, didn't hear the phone ring. Didn't hear the baby cry. I have a real doctor-verified case of selective hearing loss :) Parties Just read Quiet by Susan Cain if you care to understand.

item.title: THINGS THAT ARE BAD FOR MOST PEOPLE BUT MILD FOR ME
item.description: Dunno why. I just always get lucky. Poison Ivy This is what started this list. I got a case of poison ivy when I was maybe 8. Since then it has no effect on me. I can pull it, crush it, walk around in it and never get the slightest rash. Downside: I was Weeder-in-chief of the yard/forest border region when I was a kid. My parents used my power for their own purposes.

item.title: THINGS I'M NOT ALLERGIC TO
item.description: This is a partial list. Full disclosure: I am mildly allergic to formaldehyde and chlorine. Swimming pools make me feel kind of gross for a few hours. Latex Any medication Bee stings Tree nuts Shellfish Peanuts Wheat Please. I'd rather be dead. Egg Dairy Soy Gluten Dust Pet Dander Strawberries My poor wife. Pollen Except one spring maybe 8 years ago I had some crazy allergy thing where my nose was running constantly and my eyes itched.

item.title: PARTS OF MY NAME THAT ARE WEIRD
item.description: To keep it simple, I never correct people or try to make it accurate unless it’s important. I couldn’t care less if the gal at the restaurant puts me down as Jeff Coffee. Geoff With a G. G E O F F. Wilondek Here, I'll spell it for you. Coffey Like the drink but with an E Y on the end. Bonus item: My wife's name is Mamie If you're under 75 I'll say: Say it like "Amy" with an M in the front.

item.title: CHILDREN'S TELEVISION QUESTIONS
item.description: What was up with Caillou's hair? Also what was up with Caillou? So, can Ernie and Bert get married now? You never really saw Emily Elizabeth with a giant plastic baggie. Did anybody ever stop to think that maybe Oscar would engage with society in a more positive way if we provided him with a decent place to live? And stopped referring to him in a derogatory way? I'd be grouchy too.

item.title: COLLECTIVE NOUNS
item.description: A few of the lesser-knowns. A Cantaloupe of Antelope A Trump of Rich Racist Misogynists A Shitstorm of Shitzus A Please-Kill-Me of Parakeets A Cuddle of Crocodiles A Pedantry of Oxford Comma Demanders A Kill-Switch of Kindles A Modicum of Angry Mobs A Why of Four-Year-Olds A Laundry of List Appers A Scout of Harper Lee Novels A Contradiction of Sacred Texts A Prius of Whole Foods Shoppers A Crayola of Modern Artists

item.title: LISTS I COULDN'T PULL OFF
item.description: Add your own. People standing outside bathrooms I really wanted to make a photo list while I was at the airport but there's no good way to get these pictures.

item.title: NAMES MY CAT GOES BY
item.description: Our cat was named by my daughters years ago, squarely in the goofy kids phase. They named her Biscus because they loved the idea of coming home from school and saying, “Hi Biscus!” Like all pets, she goes by many names. Hibiscus The one that started it all. Biskybaby My daughter Isabel weighs in with this one sometimes. Bisky-bu-bums My daughter Sophia calls her this all the time. Lousy Meowsy

item.title: FAVORITE IPHONE APPS, RANKED
item.description: My Fitness Pal I'm hardly alone with this one, but this app helped me lose 55 pounds and I've continued to track my calories ever since because it just works well. Also integrates with fitness trackers like Apple Watch. This app may have added years to my life. Paprika This is my favorite recipe app. Nicely designed, easy data entry, and syncs with all my devices including my Mac.

item.title: THINGS LUCINDA WILLIAMS WAS BLESSED BY
item.description: According to her beautiful song, “Blessed”. The Minister who practiced what he preached The Poor Man who said that heaven was within reach The Girl Selling Roses who showed us how to live The Neglected Child who knew how to forgive The Battered Woman who didn't seek revenge The Warrior who didn't need to win The Blind Man who could see for miles and miles The Fighter who didn't fight for the prize

item.title: COOKIE BUTTER: A PERSONAL HISTORY
item.description: In my defense I have never been an eat-the-raw-cookie-dough type. I think chocolate chip cookie dough ice cream was the darkest period in human dessert fad history. This may have tainted my expectations. Ca. 2009: I read an online post extolling the virtues of Trader Joe's "Cookie Butter" Me: Gross Ca. 2011: I read a blog article about the best Trader Joe's hidden gems and cookie butter is high on the list.

item.title: THINGS THAT ARE HARD
item.description: Diamond Advanced Algebra Linda Hamilton in Terminator 2 Facts of anthropogenic climate change Phoenix city water Most consonants Mike's lemonade Turning out the light and going to bed when I'm away from my wife.

item.title: SOMETIMES
item.description: Assorted musings from my journal, shortened and reworded for consistency. Sometimes when I count the people in the room so I can set the right number of places at the table, I forget to count myself. Sometimes it seems hard to believe how my cat can hear me say "Get up" all the time and still not understand what it means. Sometimes when I switch my bag from one shoulder to the other while talking on the phone, I am struck by the hundreds of intricate, coordinated, proprioceptive movements it takes to do it seamlessly, and I think for a moment that the body and brain are a miracle.

item.title: DEGREES IT WAS IN PHOENIX THIS WEEK
item.description: It’s always hot in the summer in Phoenix but 117 is a special kind of hot. Monday: 105¬∞ F Tuesday: 97¬∞ F Brrrr‚Ä¶ Wednesday: 108¬∞ F Thursday: 114¬∞ F Friday: 117¬∞ F Yesterday: 115¬∞ F Today: 112¬∞ F

item.title: SUPER HEROES IN A PARALLEL UNIVERSE
item.description: Spider Man was bitten by a radioactive mosquito instead Rather than fight crime he just annoys people constantly. Signature move: Sneaks up behind you and hisses in your ear. Gear: Malaria-misters on his wrists. Incredible Hulk was hit with alpha radiation instead Still just Bruce Banner but kind of has a temper anyway. Baby Superman crashed in Moscow in 1972 instead He's a fully indoctrinated communist. Olympics are now pretty much a joke.

item.title: I FORGOT MY WALLET: A STEP BY STEP GUIDE TO STUPIDITY
item.description: Yes this really just happened. Yes I had to go back to pay. Go to Trader Joe's to buy those yummy jarred cherries for the tart your making for your daughter for her birthday. Put ten more things in your cart because hey! Berries are on sale! Realize at the checkout that you forgot your wallet. Feel a white hot searing embarrassment for a moment. Ask if they accept mobile payments.

item.title: LINES FROM JOE VS. THE VOLCANO
item.description: I love this underrated movie. It’s silly and a little weird but that’s because it is a fairy tale about capitalist greed subjugating the common man and distracting him with consumerism, which was ahead of its time for the ’80s. Best of all it is funny and even a little touching and has Meg Ryan in three parts. "What takes more courage? To twice traverse a staircase in flames or to make a one-time leap into the mouth of a smoking volcano?

item.title: THINGS ON PHOENIX PUBLIC TRANSIT
item.description: I used to ride the light rail to my office every day and sometimes came home late at night. For the most part fellow riders were normal, friendly folks. But there were a few weirdos. Fume Guy This was the strangest and saddest addiction I've ever seen. An angry man huffing horrible noxious fumes from a big bottle of some kind of industrial aerosol. The smell of the chemical brought tears to my eyes and he was sucking on it like it was mother's milk.

item.title: THINGS I SAY SARCASTICALLY
item.description: I’m kind of a jerk. I'm sure this is all true. This seems well thought out. This is unlikely to backfire. It looks like you've "done your own research." You handled that well. I'm definitely up for that. I'll log that away. Stolen from the vastly underrated Emperor's New Groove which my children adored. We should do this more often. Great meeting guys. I definitely want to try that sometime.

item.title: BOOKS I REMEMBER FONDLY FROM MY CHILDHOOD
item.description: Inspired by my feed right now. I limited this to fiction but I read mostly non-fiction as a kid. The Giving Tree Controversial I know. First, to heck with your controversy because this was my first biggest favorite thing way before I was aware enough to discern any problematic interpretation. I loved this book more than anything in the world from before I can remember. And second, to heck with your controversy because this book is lovely.

item.title: SPELLING: MY PRIVATE BATTLE
item.description: I was a lousy speller as a kid. And it spilled over to an inability to sort out strangely spelled words. This is the story of my suffering. Girl I spelled this "gril" all throughout a book report I wrote in sixth grade about a book with an unnamed gril. I still believe that in a Midwestern accent this spelling more closely matches the pronunciation. Schedule In 4th grade my teacher had those cartoony classroom decorations and one of them had this word.

item.title: ICONIC U2 GUITAR HOOKS
item.description: I Will Follow http://bit.ly/1L3bg5q Sunday Bloody Sunday http://bit.ly/1N2j7Uf Bad http://bit.ly/1N2nmPA Pride (In the Name of Love) http://bit.ly/1J3fbjg Wire http://bit.ly/1HFmE2H Where The Streets Have No Name http://bit.ly/1TqnGqj I Still Haven't Found What I'm Looking For http://bit.ly/1J3fxGF One http://bit.ly/1IYafb3 Mysterious Ways http://bit.ly/1JTCCML In a Little While http://bit.ly/1h1T8PG

item.title: MUSIC I LISTENED TO WITH MY PARENTS GROWING UP
item.description: Inspired by @originalamericantreat and @gabimoskowitz Grateful Dead My pop went to 55 dead shows from the 70s right up to their last show at Soldier Field in the mid 90s. He would often take a week or two off with my mom and hit New York, Pittsburg, Indy, and Chicago back to back. He took us to a few shows in Indy and one in North Carolina. I watched their reunion concert with him last month and he was in tears.

item.title: AFFECTING BUFFY MOMENTS
WAYS I TELL MY DAUGHTER TO STOP TALKING SO MUCH
item.description: Girl can talk. There are too many words coming out of the hole in your face. Her favorite. She asked me to tell her teachers to use this one but I did not. Sophia why don't we play a game. I talk to mom and you don't. [when telemarketers call] Sophia, it's for you! I think the cat wants you to talk to her now. You need to take a breather and so do my ears.

item.title: THE REAL BEST OF PHOENIX ACCORDING TO ME
item.description: This list is light on high end dining because I’m not a big partaker of fancy restaurants. Also it skews heavily toward stuff around my house. But everything on this list is üíØ. I guarantee it. Best Bread: Mediterra Bakehouse Technically this is in Coolidge, not Phoenix, but you can find them at the public market on Saturday mornings and Wednesday afternoons and they have a few varieties at Whole Foods.

item.title: THINGS MY CAT AND I HAVE IN COMMON
item.description: Would prefer to stay home Mammal Fond of crunchy food Covered entirely or partially with hair Turns nose up to mushy foods from a can Happy to hide in the back room when people come over Can sleep anywhere and in any position Not really that in to catnip Prefer most things to unplanned doctor visits Pretty tidy Currently shedding a bit Seriously guys, what's up with my hair? Hairs everywhere.

item.title: TEXTS FROM LAST MONTH
item.description: An exploration of the mundane, by request. From my wife. She's informing me her flight home is really truly for real cancelled. I cried. Not really but you know, I was sad. From my daughter Isabel. She had just boarded a plane. Ha ha. From my other daughter Sophia. I'm actually super embarrassed for you all to see her terrible spelling and careless typing. This is basically how all her texts read.

item.title: THINGS THAT DON'T MEAN WHAT WE THINK THEY MEAN
item.description: The Road Not Taken This poem is about not following the crowd but instead striking out in our own direction and finding our true selves, right?! No. "Though as for that the passing there / Had worn them really about the same, / And both that morning equally lay / In leaves no step had trodden black." It pointedly makes fun of our tendency to think past decisions are more important than they really are.

item.title: REASONS TO EAT LUNCH AT PANERA WHILE MY HOUSE IS UNINHABITABLE
item.description: Decent WiFi The wifi at this crap hole always works reliably. Spacious There's lots of room between tables and lots of nooks and crannies for semi-privacy. Quiet Everybody isn't YELLING and the floors are carpeted and they use little proximity dealios so they don't have to yell names. Not crowded Probably because the food is largely inedible its not super-jam-packed with people so I don't feel bad sitting here for a couple hours.

item.title: A List About Love and Punctuation
item.description: Who remembers this song from my senior year of high school? I love you. Do you love me? Please please! I want to (hold you)

item.title: THINGS I SAID TO MY DAUGHTER TO TALK HER OUT OF MAKING ME TAKE HER TO MINIONS
item.description: I have now seen minions but I did not want to. We could rent something! SOPHIA: I think we should get out of the house! Ooh. Jurassic Park has dinosaurs. Could be good? SOPHIA: Yeah but it doesn't start til 8. We could see Mission Impossible! Let's watch the preview for mission impossible! SOPHIA: That does look good. ... I hate making decisions. How do I decide? Well Minions has a Rotten tomato rating of 54%.

item.title: MALAPROPISMS AN ACQUAINTANCE HAS ACTUALLY SPOKEN OVER THE LAST COUPLE OF YEARS
PROS/CONS OF THE NEW "OPEN LIST" FEATURE
item.description: What is good about it? What is bad about it? GOOD: You can make a list with no items. BAD: You can't make a ranked open list anymore (?) GOOD: You can see the description in the feed so there's no need to corrupt the purity of the list data model with bogus items. GOOD: No more unasked for list suggestions. BAD: No more unasked for list suggestions.

item.title: GOOD SPORTS‚ûï
item.description: The drive through cashier at Hardee's in West Lafayette Indiana ca 1993 In college my friend was driving me somewhere and decided to be a dumb teen. He went to the drive through and said, "I'd like one french fry please." Without skipping a beat the cashier said "that will be 4¬¢, please drive around." He accepted a dollar, returned 96¬¢ and handed my friend a small french fry bag with a single fry.

item.title: WHAT I WOULD DO IF I HAD A TIME MACHINE
item.description: Revisit my most painful memory. Kill the mother of my mortal enemy. Kill my mortal enemy as a child. Save Buckbeak. Dress up as a Connecticut Yankee and visit king Arthur's court. Destroy It. Tour a Tralfamadorian zoo. Buy a sports almanac and save my mother.

item.title: ARGUABLY INAPPROPRIATE MOVIES MY PARENTS TOOK ME TO
item.description: The tv lists reminded me of my parents’ penchant for taking me to movies I probably shouldn’t have been at. I was the youngest and I think they just got tired of kid movies and, apparently, babysitters. Age 4: Jaws Scarred me for life. Age 7: My Dinner with Andre My friend was spending the night. When dad got home from work he said, "Want to go see a movie?" This is what we saw.

item.title: TV I WATCHED WITH MY FAMILY GROWING UP
item.description: We didn’t have a tv from birth to 5 and again from 12 to 16. And when we did have a tv I mostly watched with my brother. My mom never watched tv and my dad usually worked until close to bed time. But here’s what I remember watching together. Twin Peaks I always had to go to bed before it was over. But I thought it was cool. Murphy Brown

item.title: THINGS PEOPLE LIKE MORE THAN I LIKE ANYTHING
item.description: Sometimes I wonder what it would be like to feel. This young lady liked the Beatles more than I like anything. This woman likes puppies more than I like anything. http://bit.ly/1gyg7Bq Kristen Bell likes sloths more than I like anything. My daughter Sophia likes a huge number of things more than I like anything. These people like iPhones more than I like anything. This kid likes Hello Kitty more than I like anything.

item.title: THINGS THAT AREN'T SPICY
item.description: Everything labeled "spicy" in the Bay Area. I suspect some of the Thai places around here might be an exception.

item.title: FAVORITE MOVIES BY MY LEAST FAVORITE DIRECTORS
item.description: This list is mostly a lie. Michael Bay: Armageddon Good for a laugh. James Cameron: Terminator An actual honest to goodness awesome movie from the same ding dong that made Avatar. Wes Anderson: The Life Aquatic This guy is basically just parodying himself at this point, right?

item.title: COSMIC COINCIDENCES
item.description: Sometimes the universe likes to troll. The sun is 400 times larger than the moon and 400 times farther away. Consequently they look like they're the same size. They weren't always this way and won't always be. I imagine this messed with our understanding of the universe for a hundred thousand years or so. The 18th century Titius-Bode law stated that planets tend to orbit twice as far away as the next planet in.

item.title: THINGS I LOVE ABOUT MY üíà
item.description: Central Barber Shop / 5026 N Central Ave, Phoenix It is a block from my house. When I was a little boy and I visited my grandparents in small-town northern Indiana, my grandpa would always put on his seersucker pants and boater and walk to the barber with my brother and I. We'd all get our hair cut together. My mom even bought us our own "grandpa pants" to wear to this outing once.

item.title: PLACES I'M GOING RIGHT NOW
item.description: To the airport to pick up my wife who I haven't seen in over two weeks. ‚ù§Ô∏è Just thought you should know.

item.title: A STEP-BY-STEP GUIDE TO BUSSING A TABLE
item.description: This is for the lovely young woman at smashburger who asked twice. Is the customer actively eating? Then it's not time to take their plate yet. After that it is admittedly hard to tell.

item.title: THE MURALS OF PHOENIX
item.description: Phoenix has a wonderful culture of mostly-Mexican-inspired urban murals. They are all over the city, often tucked away so you have to wander to find them. This list is long but it isn’t close to comprehensive. I didn’t do any South Phoenix, North Phoenix, or West Phoenix, or any of the surrounding cities. I’m sure they all have examples. „Ä∞ UPTOWN „Ä∞ This is my part of town so these are all special to me.

item.description: Although I fear by making this list I will undermine its assumptions and it will stop fixing these for me. GEoff Grifff Hrodd Geiff

item.title: SHAKESPEARE MOVIES RANKED
item.description: There are lots more Shakespeare movies but these are the ones I’ve seen recently enough to comment on. The Hollow Crown from the BBC (All four plays in the first henriad) Loki from Avengers plays an impeccable Henry V along with the always-awesome Jeremy Irons as Henry IV. I'm partial to the first in the series, Richard II but all four are fantastic. Very high quality and beautiful production. Weakest link: Falstaff, which is a shame because obviously he's a big deal.

item.title: IF I WERE TRAPPED ON A DESERT ISLAND WITH ONLY THREE BOOKS
item.description: The Complete Works of Shakespeare Scrapbook of my wife and kids That's all I need. In that order. Just kidding honey.

item.title: IN WHICH I CONFESS TO A TOTAL LACK OF POPULAR CULTURE CREDIBILITY
item.description: I’m a little anti-social which might factor in to these. Please note: there’s no judgement here. I’m not suggesting these things are unworthy of time. I have great respect for our culture. I just don’t understand it sometimes or don’t feel a compulsion to engage. I’m not sure why. I've only watched one television show for its entire run in my life. I've watched bits and pieces of lots of shows of course, but never had a show I really watched except Buffy.

item.description: Bud Starling Audubon chapter president in Indianapolis, lead bird watching tours in Eagle Creek park when I was a kid. Doug Bowser Recently-appointed VP of Sales at Nintendo. Thomas Crapper Plumber and outspoken early proponent of the flush toilet. Lance Bass Sang the bass part for ‚òÖNSYNC.

item.title: THE END OF MARRIAGE: A POST-APOCALYPTIC DIARY
item.description: As you know, marriage was undermined last week. Here’s my diary of the aftermath in this lonely post-marriage outpost. I hope there’s somebody left to read this. Day 1: The beginning of the end Surprisingly my marriage is still intact. But my wife is traveling with spotty cell service so it is possible she hasn't been able to get through to me to call it off. Day 2: Churching Went to church today.

item.title: ENGLISH WORDS WITH INTERESTING BACKSTORIES‚ûï
item.description: I love words. And I especially love words that came to us in interesting ways. Here are some of my favorites. Bedlam Bedlam, meaning a scene of uproar and confusion, comes from the 14th century British insane asylum called Bedlam Hospital, a colloquial pronunciation of Bethlehem Hospital, a place notorious for chaos and poverty. Odyssey You would be forgiven for thinking that The Odyssey is called The Odyssey because it is a story about a great odyssey.

item.title: PERFECT FICTIONAL MOMENTS
item.description: Some of my favorites. When Bill Murray whispers in Scarlett Johansen‚Äôs ear at the end of Lost in Translation This is one of my favorite movies, and the ending couldn‚Äôt be more perfect. Two dissociated and alienated people make a meaningful connection that transcends language (the limits of which are thematic throughout the film) and now they must part. It is so fitting that the words they share in this final moment are not ours to hear, and would not mean anything to us if we did hear them.

item.description: The dishwasher The washing machine The ceiling fan in the master bedroom The AC intake in the family room Crickets Not my daughters who are both out of town. Why is it so quiet? üòï

item.title: PEOPLE IN AMERICA WHO DIED FROM GUNS YESTERDAY
item.description: Statistically if it’s like a typical day, 65% suicide, 30% homicide, 5% accidental. 9 people in Charleston The media and social media will obsess over these nine people for a few days. Approximately 65 other people If they were ever mentioned they're already forgotten by everyone but their loved ones because they died individually instead of in a group. Bonus item: Approximately 75 more will die today So it goes.

item.description: Neck ties I shall dangle a piece of decorative fabric down my front. The spelling of the word "subtlety" I'm sure there's some subtle reabson ibts spbelled thabt way. The concept of grave sites This is my small patch of earth forever. Related: The concept of embalming I would like to poorly preserve this final collection of matter before I bury it away never to be seen again. Rhyming words

item.description: A couple years ago my daughter’s teacher was pregnant. The teacher’s favorite book was Gatsby so Sophia decided to make her a soft baby-book version. She did the cutting and sewing. Her older sister and I did the textual adaptation. The result was arguably the coolest gift a kid has ever given a teacher. Cover The Great Gatsby Page 1 This is Nick. He likes all kinds of people. Page 2

item.title: THINGS I SILENTLY JUDGE
item.description: Over the top proposal videos When my wife and I entered into a verbal contract to marry it was ... more clinical. If you have an elaborate flash mob at your proposal I secretly hate you while I click Like in Facebook. People who are always late "Oh no it's no problem at all" he says while secretly down-rating his internal accounting of your fitness to complete any task at all.

item.title: THINGS I WANT MY KIDS TO KNOW
item.description: There's a difference between "it's not my fault" and "I can't help it." The former is common. The latter is rare. Postel's Law is just as relevant to human interaction as it is to computer communications. "Be conservative in what you do, be liberal in what you accept from others." http://bit.ly/1QDQXfI "It made me mad" is never true and sometimes blame-shifting. You cannot control what happens but you determine how you respond.

item.title: THINGS THAT MADE MY HEART SWELL AND BURST
THINGS I CAN'T OPEN RELIABLY
item.description: Cardboard milk cartons. I had these under control when I was in kindergarten but now they're an enigma. The foil under the flap in a package of Trident gum. Is it even perforated? Do I need a scalpel? Glass bottles with twist off caps. (Embarrassing) Hotel doors. Red light. Red light. Red light. Green light! Conversations with my barber. So um...any big plans for this...wednesday? Email attachments from old versions of outlook.

item.title: REASONS "ME & EARL & THE DYING GIRL" IS ONE OF THE BEST-WRITTEN MOVIES I'VE EVER SEEN
item.description: I got to see this movie the other day at an early screening. I honestly only went because I’m traveling alone and was bored and it was free. I watched the preview and thought “Meh, high school Juno-quirky comedy. Boring.” But I’m so glad I went because it was wonderful. I’m not a film buff at all but to my amateur eye the writing was superb. It makes dialog seem effortless

item.title: AN OPINIONATED LIST OF THINGS THAT DON'T BELONG ON THINGS
item.description: I’ve been away from my family for a week and I’m getting surly. You probably shouldn’t read this indulgent judgmental BS. Cranberries don't belong on sandwiches. This is what inspired this list. There should have been a large print warning in the menu. Greens don't belong on pizza. Ever. EVER. Leashes don't belong on cats. Or toddlers for that matter. Maybe there's a rare scenario where this makes sense. Phones don't belong on dates.

Doing some pre-shopping today. May be moving in a year. Naglee Park in downtown San Jose Downtown San Jose north side of Japantown [that's all I've got; anyone else?

item.title: WORDS THAT ARE USED WAY TOO OFTEN TO MEAN SOMETHING THEY DON'T MEAN
item.description: Rape Being over charged, sold something you didn't want, or humped by a dog do not meet the criteria of "rape". Find another word. Draconian Is Facebook the government? Do they cut your hands off when you chew gum? No? Then their stupid policy isn't "draconian". Finally In particular as it relates to headlines about Apple, Inc. "Apple finally adds cold fusion reactor to iPhone." "Apple finally solves world hunger".

The whole premise is that she's ugly. Problem is she's not ugly at all. She's lovely. What‚Äôs-her-name (Egg?) in Arrested Development Cute as a button. item.title: 85 Years of Pluto: Out Evolving View
item.description: We’ve known about Pluto since 1930 but it’s so small and far away that we don’t know much. Space probes have studied every planet in the solar system but we’ve never had a probe to Pluto. The New Horizons mission has its closest Pluto encounter on July 14. It will dramatically expand our understanding. Here’s how our view of Pluto has evolved. 1930: The photograph from which Clyde Tombaugh discovered Pluto

item.description: What she lacks in skill she makes up for in vision. I guess. This polka dot pitcher This Groucho-Marx-Mask-themed mug This hamburger This food bowl for our cat inexplicably containing a red dog bone This racially-diverse collection of human noses

item.title: THINGS THAT ARE UNDERRATED
item.description: Thanks @mianguyen for the suggestion. Of course it is harder to be constructive than to complain so this list took a lot more thought than THINGS THAT ARE OVERRATED. But that’s good because it made me happier in the end. People Herman Melville put it best: "See how elastic our stiff prejudices grow when love once comes to bend them." In the few cases where I've come to understand someone I judged harshly, I've always grown to love them.

item.title: MOMENTS IN SHAKESPEARE WHEN SOMEONE SHOULD HAVE SAID "WAIT A MINUTE"
item.description: The Pedant in Taming of the Shrew when Biondello hatches his plan. Biondello approaches a stranger and asks where he's from. "Padua," he says. "Ack! Don't you know the duke has declared that anyone from‚Ä¶uh‚Ä¶Padua is to be executed? But don't worry, I'll disguise you and keep you at my house so you'll be safe. You even look a lot like my dad." "Oh thank you," says the old man.

item.title: THINGS THAT ARE OVERRATED
item.description: Time to make some enemies on List App. In n Out I totally don't get it. Better than McDonald's? Sure, but so's my cat's litter box. Good? Eh, in a pinch I guess. Great? Not even close. Lousy fries, unseasoned meat, inexcusably bad cheese, poor shakes. That batman movie with Heath Ledger Any batman movie really (oh man that voice just makes me laugh and laugh) but especially this one which people seem to think is AHMAZINGGGG.

item.title: A LIST OF INTERESTING THINGS WELL EXPLAINED
item.description: The¬†singular Vi Hart‚Äôs beautiful three part exposition of the Fibonacci sequence, culminating in a clear explanation of why it shows up in plants. (Hint: It‚Äôs not magic.) Part 1:¬†http://bit.ly/1dvB7rh¬†| Part 2:¬†http://bit.ly/1HuMpDk¬†| Part 3:¬†http://bit.ly/1dvB52M This¬†bygone film from Chevrolet¬†explaining with incredible clarity the mechanics of the differential in your car. http://bit.ly/1Q8QAJE The brilliant computer scientist Grace Hopper explains a nanosecond. http://bit.ly/1RlwQVQ Preeminent physicist Richard Feynman explains what keeps trains on tracks.

item.title: WHAT I WANTED TO BE GROWING UP, CHRONOLOGICALLY
item.description: Hat tip to @ChrisK for the list idea. An archeologist. Around age 8-10. Because of dinosaurs. Indianapolis Children's Museum FTW. An author. Off and on from around 12 to 18. All through school I loved writing assignments and wanted to grow up to be a non-fiction writer. An architect. Around age 13. Not sure where this came from. Didn't last long. I have no drawing skills whatsoever and very little interest in buildings.

item.title: A LIST OF ENCOURAGING LETTERS
item.description: Letter from Stephen Fry to a fan suffering from depression. http://bit.ly/1HjewWc Letter from Carl Sandburg to his 10 year old daughter at the start of a long battle with disease. http://bit.ly/1Hxi9x3 Letter from the brilliant E. B. White to a fan worried about the bleak outlook for the human race. http://bit.ly/1c6FuHD Letter from Kurt Vonnegut to a recently widowed fan. http://bit.ly/1c6GSKl Letter from former slave Jourdan Anderson to his former master declining the offer to return.

item.title: SMART ANSWERS TO STUPID QUESTIONS
item.description: @ChrisK 's three guests at a literary dinner party Virgil, Dante, and Dan Brown because it would be interesting to watch Virgil get all embarrassed about being in Dante's Inferno and watch Dante get all embarrassed about being in Dan Brown's Inferno and watch Dan Brown get embarrassed about what an awful writer he is. And then Virgil would write an epic poem about Dan Brown and the cycle would be complete.

item.title: QUESTIONS FOR LIST APP PROS
item.description: What's up with list title input when it puts things you did not type all around your insertion point? Who agrees that we should have a "reverse numerical" list type? Is there anywhere to see a person's account name? Can I get a notification when someone comments on a list I commented on? How many List App users are there? How far back in someone's list history can you read, like and share before it becomes creepy?

item.title: THERE'S ALWAYS TIME: AN ENCOURAGING LIST FOR ANY AGE
item.description: If you are… Under 25 Good for you! Go put your dent in the universe. Under 27 At your age Ernest Hemingway had not published anything of consequence yet but he was trying. Under 30 At your age Harrison Ford was supporting his family doing carpentry work having failed as an actor. He finally landed his first significant role at 29 in George Lucas' American Graffiti. Under 35 At your age Andrea Boccelli decided to pursue a career in opera.

item.title: WHAT HAVE YOU DONE? A DEPRESSING LIST FOR ANY AGE.
item.description: If you are: Over 20 By your age Mary Shelly had published the indisputable classic Frankenstein and Jane Austen was writing Pride and Prejudice. What have you done? Over 22 By your age Carson McCullers had published The Heart is a Lonely Hunter which is staggeringly powerful and beautiful, was a great sensation upon publication, and is still considered one of the greatest American novels of the 20th century. What have you done?

item.title: REASONS @CHRISK IS AVOIDING SETTING A DATE TO COME VISIT ME, RANKED IN REVERSE ORDER OF LIKELIHOOD
item.description: Hey I thought mentions in list titles would work. Hmm. Here? @ChrisK A refrigerator has fallen on him and he can't get to his phone. He doesn't really like me and I should go to bed early and cry. He wants to be 100% sure he doesn't have a date possibility first. He's too busy playing with the new script editor in FileMaker. He's too busy making and reading lists

item.title: THINGS MY 17 YEAR OLD DAUGHTER ISABEL IS OBSESSED WITH
item.description: Well Sophie’s list was popular so now I feel like a jerk for favoring my wild spunky kid over her quiet delightful sister. At the risk of sounding like one of those insufferable parents, here’s what my other daughter is like. She’s her sister’s polar opposite, but equally awesome. Literature Here're a few of the books on her shelf. Although I'm an ebook reader through and through, I love that she's a paper book fetishist.

item.title: THINGS MY 13 YEAR OLD DAUGHTER SOPHIA IS OBSESSED WITH
item.description: She’s one of a kind and couldn’t be more awesome. Regina Spektor Here's the Regina Spektor quilt she made at grandma's house last year. The TV show Monk Here's her computer log in prompt. Michael Jackson (the man, not the music) Here's a snippet of her Internet search history. Michael J Fox Here's another snippet of her Internet search history. Slime Molds Here's her computer desktop background. Chef John from FoodWishes on YouTube

item.title: HOW TO BUILD THE NEXT FACEBOOK
item.description: Be smarter than you are. Work harder than you will. Get luckier than you can.

item.title: COVERS THAT ARE BETTER THAN THE ORIGINAL‚ûï
item.description: Bridge Over Troubled Water / Johnny Cash I never liked this song until I heard Cash's version. Now it moves me deeply. http://bit.ly/1GstLQy Every Grain of Sand / Emmy Lou Harris I loved the original but Emmy's is more haunting. http://bit.ly/1GsBv54 Can't Help Falling in Love / U2 Sublime take on an otherwise uninteresting song. http://bit.ly/1R9TsbL Clay Pigeons / John Prine The Blaze Foley original is great. The Prine version is better.

item.title: A LIST OF FASCINATING LETTERS
item.description: Contingency speech written for Richard Nixon in the event that the Apollo 11 astronauts were stranded on the moon during their historic moon landing. http://bit.ly/1SgzjlR Letter from the widow of Aldous Huxley to his brother describing in detail his recent death. http://bit.ly/1LeyvIT Letter from Kurt Vonnegut to a school board humanely and vulnerably opposing the banning of his books. http://bit.ly/1dmbBET Letter from Gene Wilder to the director of Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory with remarkably thoughtful feedback on costume sketches.

item.title: SIGNS I'M SLOWLY BECOMING AN OLD MAN
item.description: My barber has always trimmed my eyebrows and nostrils. This last time she did something with the trimmers in my ears. I've begun to think there might be foods that "tear me up inside". I've decided my next car will be more comfortable. Hairline. I'm thinner than I've been in years and yet I'm not sure my pants are roomy enough. I can only remember a movie by what pretty actor was in it.

item.title: GROSS THINGS I KIND OF LIKE
item.description: Chocodiles I hate twinkles but Chocodiles are kind of yummy. Salsa Verde Doritos The first one tastes so gross. The second one is like eh, not so bad. And then they become delicious. This effect lasts for about an hour. Those rectangular ice cream sandwiches If I think hard about them while eating they taste like plastic and butane. But if I distract myself they taste like heaven. Twizzlers

item.title: THINGS IN SHAKESPEARE THAT LITERALLY MAKE NO SENSE
item.description: If you think Shakespeare is a little hard to understand you’re not alone! These are passages nobody understands. I love that given all that’s been written about Shakespeare, and his continuous popularity since he was alive, there can still be a little mystery. Flim-flam the zim-zam? Romeo and Juliet Act 2, Scene 5: ‚ÄúScurvy knave, I am none of his flirt-gills, I am none of his skains-mates.‚Äù: Flirt-gills are apparently loose women, but nobody knows what skains-mates are.

item.title: GOOD SONGS THAT ARE REALLY MOSTLY JUST SOMEONE TALKING‚ûï
item.description: I’m a sucker for a story-song. They don’t even have to be singing. Lake Marie / John Prine Perfect in the way only John Prine can be. Perfectly written and perfectly performed. http://bit.ly/1GrfnYJ The Ballad of the Kingsmen / Todd Snider Possibly the greatest rant-song ever written. http://bit.ly/1Grfy6n The Last Great American Whale / Lou Reed I hadn't listened to this song in years. It was on some compilation album I had in high school.

item.title: WORDS CORMAC MCCARTHY SENT ME TO THE DICTIONARY FOR
item.description: Some people say Cormac McCarthy is a pretensions poseur. I’m not sure this list will help but I love that he writes unapologetically in language relevant to the time, place, and circumstance of the story. Harold Bloom calls Blood Meridian one of the great American novels, equal to Moby Dick. It is well worth the time. Just bring a dictionary. Adduce Cite as evidence.nFrom ‚ÄúBlood Meridian" Bole The trunk of a tree.

item.title: GEOFF COFFEYS IN THE WORLD
item.description: Me This other guy http://bit.ly/1JuXVTY

item.title: PLANETS, RANKED
item.description: I love them all but here’s my attempt at a ranking. Jupiter Because it convinced us things don't go around the earth. Venus Because it's phases taught us more about the structure of the universe. Saturn Because it marked the extent man's knowledge of the solar system for a hundred thousand years. And it is as beautiful in the sky as it is up close. Pluto Because I've been waiting anxiously for pictures of Pluto since I was 12 years old and we're getting them THIS SUMMER.

item.title: REASONS TO CUT YOUR BUTTERMILK BISCUITS IN RECTANGLES INSTEAD OF CIRCLES
item.description: It took me way too many years to figure this out. They look great. LOOK AT THEM. They taste the same. Actually better because they have corners, which are the ambrosia of baked things. It is way easier. Really, just use a pizza wheel or a big knife. You lose less to waste. You still have to trim the edges before you cut or they won't rise well but you keep all those perfectly usable in-between bits.

item.title: THINGS I'M EMBARASSED TO ADMIT MADE ME CRY
item.description: I’m sentimentally challenged which made reading to my girls difficult. When Beezus Quimby's mother tells her she and her sister didn't get along either when they were little. When Miri finds out why her father won't let her work in the quarry in Princess Academy When Charlotte says by helping Wilbur perhaps she was trying to lift up her own life a trifle. When Hermione tells Harry he's a great wizard

item.title: FUN THINGS TO DO IN PHOENIX
item.description: Just kidding I kind of love our backwards little city. Die of heat exhaustion Bait ultra-conservatives with liberal-talk and then get shot Get bit by a rattle snake while out for a walk Lose a small dog to a mountain lion Hug a tree and...oh it's a cactus Visit a new strip mall every week Ride the light rail from one end to the other, and then get in your car and drive where you really need to go.
